title: How can one live life to the fullest? - Quora

response.answer_text: The key to living our lives to the fullest is to simply care less about what others think. There’s a fine line between doing what we want versus being disrespectful don’t get me wrong, but more often than not I find that I hold myself out of fear of being judged. The reality is we waste tons of energy trying to maintain a public image when people could honestly care less. Our self-perception isn’t limited to how we view ourselves, it’s also what think others view us as. I call these self-limiting beliefs.  You’ve probably heard this answer a million times. Living by our own standards instead of other peoples expectations is repackaged in dozens of ways and fed back to us all the time. Books like The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck by Mark Manson, quotes from movies like “Fight Club” (which was released almost 20 years ago by the way), and comics like the one above all convey the same message. It’s a testament to how valuable this tip is; so why aren’t we living by it everyday? The truth is, ignoring other peoples opinion’s to commit to our own is a lot harder than it sounds. For example, as much as I know dropping my life to live abroad in another country for a year would be an amazing experience, it’s terribly frightening to make it happen. That sort of drastic change comes with sacrifice. Going against the grain to do what we think is right also involves breaking out of our safe zone. Living by our own expectations can dramatically change our relationships with the people around us! Staying selfish despite what your family expects of you, being the person who speaks their mind against their boss for something they believe is right, or saying no to your close friends when they want to have fun can bring forward tough ramifications.  “Living life to our fullest” isn’t all what it’s cracked up to be. Personally I’ve lost many friends who I valued dearly as I shed old values. I’ve also made new friends as I picked up new habits, but it can be hard to find that spark without a shared history. Staying with what’s comfortable and familiar is easier. On the flip-side, I’ve noticed focusing on what we want causes two things to happen: It moves control over our lives from other peoples hands into our ownIt involves embracing who we really are and letting the world judge it however they wantBy shedding the weight of outside opinion we embark on our own unique journey. It’s only when we start living our lives for ourselves that we start to live our lives to the fullest. Thanks for reading. If you like what you see feel free to follow me on Quora. I’m also open to any direct messages for feedback, thoughts, and suggestions.

The simplest answer should be by ‘Living in the moment.’ I would like to share a parable from The Book of Virtues by William.J.Bennett, about which even Robin Sharma mentioned in his book “The monk who sold his Ferrari”. It is named as “The Magic Thread” This might be quite long, but definitely worth the time! It goes something like this.. Peter was an ardent daydreamer. When he was in school, he dreamt of playing outside; when he was playing outside, he dreamed of his summer vacations. He never bothered to savour the special moments that were flying by. Often he wandered through the forest, dreaming of the future. One such day, he began to grow sleepy, so he lay down on the soft forest floor under the warm sun. As he began to fall asleep, he heard a voice calling his name. As he slowly opened his eyes, he saw an old woman standing before him. She held a silver ball in her hand, from which dangled a silken gold thread. “Peter!” She started, “this is the thread of your life. If you pull the thread just a bit, an hour will pass in seconds. If you pull harder, whole days will pass in minutes. And if you pull with all your might, months – even years – will pass by in days.” Peter was very excited and enquired if he could have that thread. The elderly woman quickly reached down and gave the ball with the magic thread to the young boy. The next day, Peter was sitting in the classroom feeling restless and bored. Suddenly, he remembered his new toy. As he pulled a little bit of the golden thread, he quickly found himself playing in his garden. Realising the magic he had in his hands, Peter soon grew tired of being a schoolboy and longed to be a teenager, with all the excitement that phase of life would bring. So again he held the ball and pulled hard on the golden thread. Suddenly, he was a teenager with a very pretty girlfriend named Elise. His teenage was short-lived as boredom struck him hard. He wasn't content. He now dreamed of being an adult, so again he pulled hard on the thread and many years flew by in an instant. Now he found that he was transformed into a middle-aged uncle. Elise was now his wife and Peter was surrounded by a houseful of kids. He noticed that his once jet-black hair had started to turn grey and his once youthful mother, whom he loved so dearly had grown pale, weak and frail. Peter wasn't delighted with that either. So once again, he pulled on the magic thread and waited for the changes to appear. Peter now found that he was in his nineties. His thick hair had turned white and thin and the love of his life, Elise, had also grown old and had passed away a few years earlier.His wonderful children had grown up and left home to lead lives of their own. For the first time in his entire life, Peter realised that he had not taken the time to embrace the wonders of living. He had never spent quality time with his kids or went for a long walk with Elise. He had never planted a garden nor had he read out those wonderful books to his children which his mother read. Instead, he had hurried through life, never resting to relish the journey. Peter became very sad at this discovery. He decided to go out to the forest where he used to walk as a boy to clear his head and warm his spirit. He laid down on a small patch of grass and instantly dozed off. After only a minute, he heard someone calling out to him. He looked up in astonishment to see that old woman who had given him the ball with the magic golden thread many years earlier. “How have you enjoyed my special gift?” she asked. “At first it was fun, but now I hate it.” he responded bluntly, “My whole life has passed before my eyes without giving me the chance to enjoy it. Sure, there would have been sad times as well as great times, but I haven’t had the chance to experience either. I feel empty inside. I have missed the gift of living.” She remarked Peter’s ungratefulness, but agreed to grant one last wish. “I’d like to go back to being a schoolboy and live my life over again,” Peter immediately exclaimed and returned to sleep. Again, he heard someone calling his name and opened his eyes. He was absolutely delighted to see his mother standing over his bedside. She looked healthy and radiant. Peter realised that the strange woman from the forest had indeed granted his wish and he had returned to his former life. “Hurry up, Peter. You are going to get late for school today!” she exclaimed. Needless to say, Peter dashed out of bed and went on to live a full life, the one with equal amounts of joys and sorrows, equal amounts of love and hatred, but it all started when he realized the significance of living in the moment. So when times are hard on you, don’t wish that you could skip ahead to better days. Don’t live constantly looking forward to a holiday. Don’t wish for the time to pass. Rather, savor every moment; live in the present. Life is short, and it is over in a blink. Live it to the fullest. Live in the moment. Cheers. :) MD

A weird and somewhat morbid thought occurs to me from time to time. When I am on a plane and the turbulence hits, when a car veers out into traffic, when I hear about someone I know who died suddenly: I don’t get scared. I just think, “If this is it, alright.” This is a wonderful place to be. So while it might seem morbid to say that I’d be happy going at any moment, it’s actually a wonderful way to live. It’s something I feel quite lucky to be able to say. And yet, I also know that it wasn’t a result of luck, but of a certain philosophical way of thinking and, of course, a lot of hard decisions. Here are 40 things that I believe helped me reach this point where I can say, “I’ve lived a full life.”  1. Do Ridiculous Things There’s no story behind how my wife and I came to own a goat except that we asked ourselves: Why not? So we got a goat and had Smitty’s BBQ on the way home and called it a day.  2. Not What Will Pay The Most, But What Will Teach Me The Most? This is how I have evaluated my career and job opportunities (and book projects too). There are lots of ways to make money, fewer real opportunities to learn. 3. Quit Dicking Around The books I’ve been fortunate enough to write were not the result of mad sprints of intensity. I get up every day and work on them. One right after another. While I’m waiting for one to come back from the printer, I am hard at work on the next one. Basically, I’m not dicking around. 30 years is so much time. One year is so much time. Wake up every day and do a little more. Dick around a little less. See what happens. 4. “The Right Time is Right Now.” This is Casey Neistat’s line. It’s great. When I moved to a farm, do you know how many people I heard from telling me they’ve always wanted to do that? Let me tell you, it wasn’t a tough vetting process. It’s not like getting into Harvard. If you think you want to do it, do it. 5. Get Married. Be in a Long Term Relationship. People say they want to end up with someone, they say they want to get married someday, and then what do they do? Everything but what makes that possible. Pick a person and be in a relationship already. It’s the best thing you will ever do. It’s a lot of work. It will be painful and tough at times. But it is better than the affluenza of Tinder. I’m not saying settle, but I am saying that relationships are great because you make them great, not because you search until you magically find one that’s already perfect. And enough with this polyamory nonsense. Maybe it makes .01% of the population happier, but the fact that they need to sell everyone on it so much makes me think it’s probably not working for them either. Neil Strauss wrote a wonderful book about this, don’t waste a decade of your life being an idiot. 6. Steer Clear of Charlatans and the Toxic Regular friend purges are a must. So are influence purges (the sources of information you follow). You become who you know. You conform to your surroundings. Make sure those two facts are taking you in a direction you want to go. 7. Keep a Journal Each morning, usually after a long walk on my farm, I go upstairs to my office and pull out three small notebooks. In the first one—a small blue gold leafed notebook—I write one sentence about the day that just passed. In the next, a black moleskine, I journal two quick pages about yesterday’s workout (how far I ran or swam), what work I did, any notable occurrences, and some lines about what I am grateful for, what I want to get better at, and where I am succeeding. And then finally, I pick up The Daily Stoic Journal to prepare for the day ahead by meditating on a short prompt: Where am I standing in my own way? What’s the smallest step I can take toward a big thing today? What blessings can I count right now? Why do I care so much about impressing people? What is the harder choice I’m avoiding? Do I rule my fears, or do they rule me? How will today’s difficulties show my character? The whole ritual takes maybe 15 minutes and then it’s done. By the time I am finished, I am centered, I am calm and most importantly, I am primed to do the actual creative work by which I make my living. 8. Hell Yes or Hell No is Too Simple Most of the best decisions I made would have failed that test. I was scared. I had doubts. I didn’t know if it was what I really wanted. Life is complicated and life decisions are about weighing the odds, not black and white certainties. 9. Live in New York or Los Angeles (Or a City Like That) …but not for long. It’s good to test yourself in a big city. It’s good to feel the energy of millions of people coursing through your veins. But leave before you become jaded by it or addicted to it. Leave before it changes your lifestyle. 10. The Quiet Moments Are The Best There is a line from Lao Tzu. “Peace is in the emptiness. Emptiness is in the fast of the mind.” It’s in the quiet, still moments that we feel what matters in life. Standing on the shore of a lake. Looking out over a canyon. Resting your head against someone else’s. It’s a shortage of these moments that give rise to the feeling that we haven’t lived enough, that we have to keep going. Seeking them out, encouraging them is what makes you feel like you’ve done plenty. 11. Have a Philosophy Pete Carroll talks about his turning point as a coach, when he realized he was just winging it. So he stopped and wrote down his entire coaching philosophy. Now he has something to measure himself against. “Man is pushed by drives,” Viktor Frankl once observed, “but he is pulled by values.” What are those values? When presented with a choice–which path do you choose? What rules do you live by? Well, what’s yours? Don’t wing it through your 20s. Sketch them out. They’re easier to follow that way. Focus. Live by something. 12. Make Time For Real Philosophy Too As Seneca said, “Of all people, only those are at leisure who make time for philosophy, only those are really alive. For they not only keep a good watch over their own lifetimes, but they annex every age to theirs.” 13. Exercise Every Single Day Don’t let yourself get to the point where you feel like some day in the future you’d like to lose weight or be in shape. Be in shape. Make exercise part of your job, part of your duties as a human being. Let endorphins be something you give yourself every day.  14. Don’t Compare Yourself To Other People Caesar famously wept at the feet of a statue of Alexander the Great. “Do you not think it is matter for sorrow that while Alexander, at my age, was already king of so many peoples, I have as yet achieved no brilliant success?” he http://said.Um, you were both fucking terrible. And now you’re both gone. Who cares whether so-and-so did this or that earlier than you? Who cares that so-and-so had more? 15. Sooner Is Not Better I had this idea that I wanted to be a millionaire by 25. Where this number came from, I don’t know. I made it up, it was ego, and I didn’t hit it. But you know what the difference of getting there a little later was? Nothing. No one throws you a party. Accomplishments don’t change who you are. 16. Meditate on Your Mortality The whole point of this post: Don’t shy away from thinking about death. Reminding ourselves each day that we will die helps us treat our time as a gift. Someone on a deadline doesn’t indulge himself with attempts at the impossible, he doesn’t waste time complaining about how he’d like things to be. They figure out what they need to do and do it, fitting in as much as possible before the clock expires. They figure out how, when that moment strikes, to say, Of course, I would have liked to last a little longer, but I made a lot of out what I was already given so this works too. Think about death a lot. I like Marcus Aurelius’s line: “Are you afraid of death because you won’t be able to do this anymore?” For “this” plug in so much of the crap we waste our time with.  17. Be Responsible I have a life insurance policy. I have money saved. If something happens to me, people I care about will be taken care of. The Avocado Toast guy was right. A lot of people are spending money on shit they can’t afford and then they want to blame other people for it. 18. But Not Too Responsible The reason they will be taken care of and that I feel creatively and professionally satisfied, is that I have taken a lot of big risks. I dropped out of college (this gave me a two-year head start on a lot of people). I left a good job. I bit off more than I could chew many times. 19. The Two Play Off Each Other Why could I take those risks? Because I had been responsible. I had money saved. I knew what was important to me. I had built a support network. I eliminated the tiny risks so I could take the right ones. I wasn’t spinning the “How will I pay my bills this month?” wheel like so many people unnecessarily are. As I said, do the irresponsible things — because it averages out the ultra-responsible choices you made elsewhere. 20. Don’t Live Like Every Day Is Your Last In The Daily Stoic, I say that living every day like it’s your last is insane. That would mean zero planning or foresight. Instead, live like it’s the last day of before a deployment. You’d handle your business. You’d spend time with loved ones. You’d cherish your alone time. You’d have fun. That’s how you should live day to day. 21. Travel (With Purpose) Nothing has wasted more millennial time than the cult of travel for its own sake. So you’ve been to Africa? And? So you’ve spent a month in hostels in Thailand? Yes? What did you really learn there, that you couldn’t have gotten from some other source? What did you really do? What was the purpose of any of it? Wisdom doesn’t come from going places. Not if you, as Emerson said, “brought ruins to ruins.” 22. Be Prematurely Old I’ve always had trouble relating to kids in my generation. Other than my wife and a few exceptions, most of my friends are much older and always seem to have been. As I’ve achieved some semblance of success, my peers have tended to be older too. The result is that I feel old all the time. When I hear someone say they are ‘adulting’ like it’s a funny exception to how they normally are, I think, “There is a person who is going to wake up one day and think about where all the years went.” But when you hear someone is an “old soul,” you think, “Man, they have their shit together.” Young people are stupid. Old people are wise. Which do you want to be? 23. Remember the Law of Diminishing Returns For instance with travel — it’s great, but two years of backpacking through Europe is two years of your life. Who is to say you have that much time? Chances are, at some point, you extracted most of the value of whatever it is you’re doing, but you’re just coasting now. A year in New York can be transformative, ten years will ossify you. Be willing to call things when the diminishing returns set in, it’s how you move on when others are stuck. 24. Study the Lives of the Greats Read Plutarch. Read Vasari. Read Caro’s biographies of LBJ. Not to compare yourself, as I said, but to learn. The dissections of the lives of powerful, ambitious people will teach you so much, and save you some much pain and heartache and disaster. 25. Don’t Waste Time Being Offended God, how much precious energy is spilled fighting online, shouting in other people’s faces. A well-ordered person never thinks, “How dare they?” because they don’t have those kinds of expectations of other people and they don’t think their own feelings are other people’s problem. 26. Buy a House Not at 20, not before you can afford it obviously, and not some expensive albatross that weighs you down, but something reasonable, that you love. If I had bought an apartment I’d look at when I was 22, I don’t know if I would have left my job to become a writer. If I hadn’t bought a house when I was 26, I don’t think I would have truly understood what I wanted out of life and where I was happy — I’d still be moving, still be too busy. Owning a home is having a home. It’s somewhere I want to get back to. The center I revolve around. My friend Nils likes to say that people who don’t own walls with art on them are running from something. I think he’s right. 27. Work a Lot Everyone loves to repeat that line, “On your deathbed, you won’t be happy you worked so much.” Um, I’m very proud of what I do. I will be reflecting happily on all of it. What no one sits there and thinks is how glad they are that they got good at video games, how many restaurants they ate at, the time they spent chasing girls or boys, or political arguments they got into. There are many many many more wasteful and regrettable things we do than work.Pouring yourself into something you believe contributes to the world is one of the best ways to feel content and accomplished. Don’t sell this short. 28. Drive across the United States No one should die before they have done this. 29. Psychedelics Are A Dead End I certainly have smart friends who will disagree with this, but I haven’t heard a single person tell me something they learned on psychotropic drugs that couldn’t have been learned quietly sitting with their own thoughts. I haven’t heard anything from them that I haven’t heard in a book. If your trip to the jungle in Peru is the magical solution to all your problems, you’re going to be sorely disappointed. You’re looking for shortcuts. Life is not found in shortcuts, but in doing the hard stuff (and if it really did work, then why are do they need to them over and over and over again? Hallucinogens are to insight what Oxy is to pain relief). 30. Don’t Be A Hater My biggest regret is time I have spent being envious or jealous or hating. Hating doesn’t make anyone better. It only makes you unhappier. “Hate will get you every time.” Life is too short. Find what you love about people, what you can be grateful for in them, even if that is a minor part of them. 31. Read Books. Lots of Them Any fool can learn by experience, I prefer to learn by the experiences of others, is how Bismark put it. The amount of dumb things I’ve managed to avoid because I learned the lesson in advance? Too many to count.  32. Have a Kid I used to see people in restaurants with kids and sort of pity them. The other day I was in a restaurant with my kid, having a great time and then I realized: Shit, these people have been having all the fun. I was the one being an idiot.Obviously, I would like to live until I’m 90 so I can spend as many years as possible with my son, but as Paul Kalanithi says in When Breath Becomes Air, every minute you do have is a blessing and comfort. 33. Seriously, You Can Do Whatever You Want That Steve Jobs line about how the rules were made up by people no smarter than you. Make sure you’re not conforming to needless constraints about how to dress, how to live, what’s important, how things must be done. The more value you deliver in life, the most freedom and power you have. 34. Avoid Competition Sometimes competition makes you better, but more often than not, as Peter Thiel explained, it just eats up resources. Don’t spend precious years of your life in trench warfare or in a stalemate. Go where there is no competition — seek out the blue oceans. The best way to do that? Be you. Do only the things you can do. 35. Know Your Why You have to know why you do what you do — what you prize and what’s important to you. Or you will be endlessly comparing yourself against other people, which will not only be a major distraction, it will make you miserable. 36. Know What’s “Enough” If you don’t know what “enough” is, then the default answer is always more. More money, more promotions, more attention. You have to know when you can say no — so you don’t overreach and lose it all. 37. Get the Big Things Right There’s the old Benjamin Franklin line about being a penny wise but a pound foolish. It’s the same thing with time management. Most people get the little things right and the big things wrong — and then wonder why they don’t get much done. 38. A To-Do List Every Day Every day, have a to-do list. Even on the weekends. A simple, straightforward one. One notecard, 5-6 big items and that’s it. Every day, I cross these off and tear up the card. That’s it. That’s the system. Not because it’s about drowning yourself in work, but so you can always be moving forward. Check the stuff off, don’t wing it. Use Tim Ferriss’s question: “If this were the only thing I accomplished today, would I be satisfied with my day?”  39. Design The Ideal Day So many people have big goals for the future. I think it’s better to know what your perfect day looks like. If you don’t know what your ideal day looks like, how are you ever going to make decisions or plans for ensuring that you actually get to experience them on a regular basis? It’s important to take an inventory of the most enjoyable and satisfying days of your life. What did you do? Why did you like them? Now be sure that your job, personal life, even the place you’ve chosen to live takes you towards these, not away from them. I know my ideal day and more importantly, I know when I have gotten too far from it. Life is too short to not live the way you want. 40. Learning Is Not Enough It’s very easy for learning to go in one ear and out the other. Making a concerted effort to record and process what you’re observing and being taught helps prevent that. If you read a lot, take notes on what you read and transfer those notes into a commonplace book, where you can organize your thoughts. Repeating and reiterating what you’ve learned helps make connections and improve memory. Organizing it into a system means it will be so much easier to retrieve when you need it. *** I’ll end this post with a paragraph from Mozart, who lived to be 35 but filled those years with many, many decades of life and work. “I have now made a habit of being prepared in all affairs of life for the worst. As death, when we come to consider it closely, is the true goal of our existence, I have formed during the last few years such close relationships with this best and truest friend of mankind that his image is not only no longer terrifying to me but is indeed very soothing and consoling, and I thank my God for graciously granting me the opportunity of learning that death is the key which unlocks the door to our true happiness. I never lie down at night without reflecting that — young as I am — I may not live to see another day. Yet not one of all my acquaintances could say that in my company I am morose or disgruntled. For this blessing I daily thank my creator.”  Like to Read? I’ve created a list of 15 books you’ve never heard of that will alter your worldview and help you excel at your career. What is that one thing by knowing which everything else becomes known? This is a question of the Mundaka Upanishad. ‘How does one start living life to the fullest?’ is the same question in a beautiful modern format. I really liked the question. Do you know the Plato’s allegory of cave?  A group of men and women chained to a wall in a huge deep cave, facing a wall only, ever looking at the shadows projected on the wall, of animals and objects crossing the narrow entrance, in the light of huge fire behind them inside the cave. These people believed the shadows alone to be true, and this was their reality! One day, one of them happened to get out of the entrance to the outer world and found the dazzling sun, trees, and nature. He was stupefied. He felt miserable at being so foolish at restricting himself to the confines of the cave. He went inside to share the truth with other prisoners but they called him a heretic. This is our story too. We have created a world of our own with the five senses and the mind (the software) fitted to this physical body (the hardware). We believe only in this. If somebody were to tell us anything other than this, we would consider him foolish. I am presenting a beautiful idea of the conversation of twins by Dr Wayne Dyer, inside the mother's womb, in my own words. First Twin : ‘Are we ever going to get out of this place?’ Second Twin: ‘You fool, where do we go? This is our permanent world.’ First Twin: ‘How long can we be here, there must be some other place that we can go after getting out of our mother’s womb?’ Second Twin: ‘Fool, where is this mother’s womb? There is no mother or anyone. We are on our own. We will never go anywhere.’ First Twin : ‘Maybe we are growing and preparing ourselves for some other life outside this place?’ Second Twin: ‘I have never seen a fool like you. What is this meaningless outside, you are speaking about? Your feeling of ‘something outside’ is an illusion. There is nothing beyond this. This is everything'. First Twin: ‘I somehow feel that there is a lot of light outside and a large world waiting for us.’ Second Twin: ‘You are a real dumb fellow. How do you believe something without perceiving. Perceiving is believing. What is ‘here and now’ alone is real and there is nothing beyond this'. First Twin: ‘I have some intuition that we are going to be born into another world where we can walk, run, talk, and enjoy freely without the limitation of the womb and the umbilical cord.’ Second Twin: ‘I have never seen a fool like you. This alone is true. We will not go anywhere from here'. One who thinks like the first foetus and takes this world as a passing phase and tries to see beyond the senses and mind is actually a wise man of wisdom. He is the one who lives a full life. The other person who thinks like the second foetus and takes this world alone to be real and believes that there is nothing beyond this is a finite miserable person. If we want to live life to the fullest, we have to cross the barrier of the five senses and mind and stop our habituation to time and space. When we understand that this life is just a play, a passing show, we live happily. We do not involve ourselves in meaningless, trivial things like hoarding, showing-off, seeking recognition, and other such exercises that lead to misery. Getting rid of this limitation is bliss. We get rid of misery when we wriggle out of the world created by this gadget of the five senses. This world that is created by the human body limits us to this finite world like the foetus limited to the darkness of the womb. Wake up! See beyond the senses, time and space! That state is the “Just be” state of bliss. Enjoy this bliss. Make life Simpler - Most problems are very straight-forward. Do not make them more complicated than they need to be. Instead ask yourself what is actually missing? What is the one thing you need to solve this problem? Everything else, while not irrelevant, makes your problem exponentially more complex.Example: If you need more money then find a second job, ask your boss what it would take to be promoted, or start doing some freelance work.Example: If you want to find love then go on more dating sites, go out more often and get to know more people.Only commit to what you will do - Especially to yourself you want to be honest. Either you do what you said you would do or you do not say it. When you do what you said you would you strengthen your belief in yourself and all following actions.Move faster - Do more. Move more. Have so much going on that you have to run everywhere you go. The reason you are bored or lead a lesser life is simply because you have too few things going on. Fill your schedule with amazing things where you can so that you do not get sucked into apathy and instead get excited.Example: Why do you think kids are so happy? The ones that are the most active not only sleep the best but also have the most fun.“Just Do It” - Your thoughts are the biggest things keeping you from a better life. In an attempt to find a better solution you often think yourself out of action and into inaction. Honestly though, you already know what to do… you just need to go and do it! Don’t think. Act!Keep Learning - Be honest here: How many hours are you investing into your own learning or improvement? How many books have you read? How many courses have you paid for? How much have you invested in your own growth this last year, both financially and time wise? With the numbers, or even the lack of numbers in front of you, is it really that surprising that you are where you are?Chase Joy wherever you can - Life is not made amazing by getting rid of the stressful and the negative things. It is not by thinking about how to save what you have that you create a great life but by trying to create more of what makes life fun for you! Try to chase joy every day. Keep a list of things that make you smile, actively create plans to have fun, and set the intention to have a great time before you enter a situation.Become Personally Responsible for Everything - This is YOUR life. You are responsible for how you live it. So start acting more in line with your own interests instead of reacting to the choices made by others. Your life could be so much better if you took responsibility for where you are and how you felt and acted accordingly. It will not get better by denying what is happening.Let go of things that do not matter - What you did before is irrelevant now. You are not that person anymore and holding onto choices made by that person does nothing for you. Let go of the things that do not matter and focus on what does. Keep your mind clear of regret or worries of the future so you have more energy to spend right now!Learn to Smile - Not just smiling about things that bring you fun, but also about things that go wrong. Keep a sense of humor about everything that happens in your life, for your time is far too precious to waste it in fear. Besides, if you cannot change it there is no point to worrying, as it will remain the same whether you worry or not. And if you can change it, there is no point to worrying either, as it will change and not be what you worried about before. So smile, believe that you can figure it out and let it be what it is.

I was having ‘the talk’ with my ex-boss, telling him stuff about my life, next job and aspirations. I was sobbing while telling him how everything is making me feel that I am useless. It was a conversation which had discussions, advices and a life-changing lesson. In the middle of the conversation, he said, Unnati, you are running behind small things, you do not value the big opportunities which will give you results in the future. And because you think about the present and not the future, you may regret the life that you are making. It did not make sense at that point in time. I thought that was just a way to demean an already broken soul but after a year of struggles, opportunities and learnings, his words make sense.  Here is a story: This is your life when you are born. An empty jar which you can fill with anything.  Now, you put golf balls inside the jar of life. These golf balls are the important things in your life. Like your parents, studies, career, good deeps, a few friends and some dreams.  Now, you put in the secondary things in life. Your car, job, house, phone and the social life that you portray on social media. These are like pebbles. What would have happened if the sand filled the jar first? There would be no space for the golf balls or the pebbles. This is what we do with our lives. We worry about things which are not under our control and overthink about the situations or people. We fill our jar with unimportant things and let go of the important things. But if we would act smart and put the golf balls first, trust me, we would live life to the fullest.  To live life to the fullest you ought to have a priority list. You have to decide what deserves your time and what does not. You have to be a bit selfish at times. Because you just have one jar! By Losing It All  I moved to another country by myself when I was a teenager. What was interesting was that while I knew this was going to be a big life event, I never fully understood at the time how profoundly it would change my understanding and appreciation of life. To begin, a bit of a background. I had a very well to do childhood. My parents were both doctors, I studied at one of the best international schools in Asia and overall my quality of life was very high. I had people to cook for me, clean for me, take care of me, etc. I had great friends and was close to my family. Anything I could ever think of was available to me. It was all fantastic… until the day I landed at O’Hare Airport with three bags and big dreams. I moved to Chicago for college when I was 16. I was a few days short of my 17th birthday when I stepped out into the humid summer air and took in what was to be my new home for the near future. It all seemed fair and dandy until life hit me in the face a few hours later. I showed up to college after traveling 24+ hours to be told that there was no space in the dorms for me. Fantastic. So I walk around the neighborhood with my bags like a vagabond till I find a for rent sign on a tiny 450 sqft apartment (that was stupidly overpriced in retrospect) and I take it. Since I’m technically a minor the can’t rent it to me so I became very familiar with the legal system and how it worked that day. Tried opening a bank account shortly after, and same thing. I then go out shopping to find some furniture for my apartment. I realize I don’t have a clue what to look for. I end up buying some decent furniture and losing a lot of money in the process. I’d never setup a bed from scratch before so that learning came quick. Once all this toil is done, I sit down and see I’m extremely hungry. I quickly realize outside of making ramen I have little to no experience in preparing food and don’t have the money to go eat out. I went to bed hungry that night. The following day I realized I’d never really done laundry before. Went through and started doing that and completely messed everything up and lost some clothes. Amazing. During all of this I wish I could’ve just called over to my mom and asked her to come help me out. Unfortunately she’s thousands of miles away and I’m soon to be a grown man so I had to learn all this stuff for myself. Moreover, I’m very close to my parents so I missed their company and being able to hang out with them. Without getting too verbose, I think you get the point. I had everything I could ever want and I never appreciated it. Then I had it all taken away from me and truly understood how much every little experience really meant. You can read some of my other answers to read more about my experience growing up in a foreign land. The cycle of events for me was very interesting. It started with being clueless, then frustration because I didn’t get what I wanted, then acceptance of what I didn’t have, then thankfulness for what little I did have and the journey to begin learning and growing what I wanted, and finally massive appreciation when I slowly started to get things back. I had to have it all taken away from me and slowly reintroduced back in my life for me to truly appreciate and “live” life. Whereas before I’d bitch and cry about how something didn’t taste just right, now I’m thankful if I can just sit down and share a meal with someone I love. I’ve learned that living life to the fullest means being dragged through the mud and coming out better for the wear. It’s an appreciation for the beauty in all things, large and small, and that miracles happen everyday in each of our lives. Living life to the fullest is recognizing the power and magic of relationships with those we love, the blessings of good health and sound mind, and trying to make the world a better place for those that come after us. Sometimes the best things in life have to be taken away for one to realize how much they were truly worth to begin with. It’s the combinations of these things, large and small, which is what makes life worth living.

The secret to living life to the fullest is hiding in plain sight, but can’t be grasped by thought. It’s crazy how simple it is. It’s also a secret that I wish I was aware of a long time ago. As human beings, we are constrained within time, which contains past, present, and future (or so we think). The truth is, there is no such thing as the past or the future - they are mental creations of the mind. This ultimately means time (in the psychological sense) is an illusion. There is only NOW. There is only THIS moment. Life is always happening through the now. Look at animals. Look at children. Look at nature in general. They are always rooted in NOW. Many people are not “here”, many people are stuck in their heads thinking about the past or anticipating the future. This means many people can’t take effective action in the present, which is the only way you can live life.  A long time ago, I used to look towards the future as salvation from my unsatisfactory life. When I get jacked, then I’ll be happy. When I get out college, I’ll have a better life. When I get to X age, everything will make sense. When I become good at guitar, then I’ll feel accomplished. When I make a certain amount of money, then all of my worries will disappear. All of these things happened, but guess what? There was still this gnawing sense of unease. Then, more future projection started to happen. I realized what I was doing: mortgaging my happiness in the present for some future that may or may not happen. I was so dissatisfied with what was going on NOW that I needed an escape. Why couldn’t I be content looking out the window on a nice day? Why couldn’t I accept my feelings instead of trying to bury them? Why couldn’t I just be fine with whatever happened?  If you want to live life to the fullest, accept and embrace NOW. Realize that you must take action and don’t put things off to some imaginary “some day”. Some day will become right now, eventually. If you’re in a bad situation, just accept it. Feel the entirety of your situation. Don’t run from it, don’t hide from it. Realize that the situation will change, just like the weather does. You might be depressed. Embrace your sadness. You might be heartbroken. Embrace your anguish. You might be out of a job. Embrace your unemployment. Accept all these things as the tide of your life. The present moment is a doorway. It is a gift. It is an opportunity to become “one with life” and make things happen. But if you don’t see that opportunity, if you don’t get out of your own way, you will never live a great life. You will always be projecting the past onto the current moment, which creates your future. That means your life will be one, long, monotonous string of repetition and nonfulfillment. Be aware and awake to what is. If you do that, the rest will take care of itself.

To me, it seems that the way in which we can live our lives to the fullest comes about as a result of mastering the abstract dualities of reality. Life is filled with a complex amalgam of contradictory dualities. The key to a full life is to strike the right balance between hundreds of these pairs of abstractions. The only problem is that the “right” balance varies depending on the environment, the society, and not to mention the individual. Let me go over one of the most common human dualities and what I think the right balance could ideally look like for it. Repetition vs. Experimentation In any endeavor, we need repetition to practice the skills that go with what we’re doing. Without redundancy, we can never develop mastery. For example, a basketball player who wants to improve their shooting percentage would naturally want to practice by taking several hundreds of shots per day. However, repetition is often not enough. We also need experimentation to find new methods and techniques for achieving our aims which we never thought of before. I am going back to the example of the basketball player. Maybe he is shooting thousands and shots per day and seeing little improvements. However, if he adjusted his shooting form and the timing of his jump, he could completely change his shot and see massive improvements. To do that, he must experiment and be willing to venture into uncharted territory. Changing the way you’ve shot the ball for years is awkward and missing many more shots than you’re used to will feel embarrassing. The master once again becomes the fool to propel himself to a higher plane. This is what people mean by working smart vs. working hard. One path is repetition, and one is strategic experimentation. One builds you up, the other tears you down so you can begin anew and build yourself up into something better. But then, some people are overly experimental and don’t put enough repetition into their activities. If we try to do everything and be everyone, we end up accomplishing nothing and becoming nobody. That’s why striking a balance between repetition and experimentation is so important for finding fulfillment in your aims. But this duality doesn’t just apply to your work life or hobby. It applies to every single aspect of life. For example, to maintain a romantic relationship, you have to do a lot of repetitive things for the other person that keep things together. Cheering them up after a bad day at work. Going to the grocery store to purchase supplies together. Making them coffee or sending them loving text messages. Repetition and order are necessary to keep the relationship stable and supportive. However, experimentation is also necessary. Without testing and controlled chaos, the relationship will quickly grow stale and collapse in on itself. Going out together to a new event in town. Challenging each other to grow on a personal level. Making significant life changes together, such as having children or moving to a new city. These are the activities that open the doors to the unknown and allow for exploration in hopes of finding something better. Without experimentation, one or both partners will seek something new in the form of another person to be with. However, too much experimentation and instability will destroy the relationship just the same. That’s what it means to have three arguments a day for a month. It seems to me that the right balance between repetition and experimentation is something like 80/20. 80% of our actions should be repetitive, maintaining order and building mastery. The remaining 20% of our actions should be experimental, somewhat chaotic, and on the quest for novel experiences. Too much repetition leads to a stale life that will feel like more of a grind than anything else. Forty years later and you’re filled with regrets about things you didn’t get to experience. But it’s too late because you’re old and weak, and your life is nearly finished. On the other hand, too much experimentation and experience-seeking in life will lead to a fragmented identity. Twenty years later and you still don’t know who you are, what you do, or what your place is in the world. That’s a scary place to be, primarily as an older adult. Balance. I suspect that it’s not 50/50 for most people. But, find the right balance for you. —Karim

As you brush your teeth every night before bed, think of ONE single thing you're grateful for. Write down ONE thing in your life that is unhealthy right now and that you can have control over (nutrition, hydration, smoking, weight, excessive caffeine, exercise, etc). You cannot, if you have to ask that question. Because Life is full right now. What is blocking you from seeing that is:a) Your own ideas of how a ‘full life is supposed to look like’! b) Refusal to believe that what you seek is something you already have. Look at this disappointed tourist. His travel agent promised him a ‘rose garden’ but took him to a flower paradise instead. The tourist cannot enjoy the paradise. Because that is not what he is looking for.  “But your tourist itinerary said it would be a ‘bed of roses’. I do not see roses.” Of course if you point that out to him, he will say its not about the flowers but about ‘commitment’, ‘business ethics ‘, ‘principles’ and so on. But can he see that his own good beliefs are coming in the way of his own goal : enjoy the present moment of his tour to the fullest.  This is how our typical definitions look like:What is the least you need to be happy? Stable job, spouse, kids, a car, house OR Well paying job, beautiful spouse, no kids, a car, house with high-speed internet. What is the best you need to be happy?My own billion dollar business like Facebook, fame for some art skill(singing, playing music, photography etc…to earn the badge of a ‘multi talented personality’) spouse, bigger car, bigger house. OR My own billion dollar business like Facebook, no spouse, chartered plane, houses on multiple islands. And of course high-speed internet. The permutation/combinations might vary but an entire human’s life is being defined by 4 things! a) Means of earning, b) place of stay, c) family members and d) people’s opinions? This is just an illustrative example. The takeaway is that often we have very rigid ideas of what will make us happy. The question is: What if you get something different? Something better? Would you be able to appreciate it? What if you get sweet, spring water and you are waiting around with a ruler to measure the ‘good things in life’? But that is assuming you HAVE something worth appreciating right? Right. So let’s look at something to be sad about. Tragedy #1: Have good education but don’t have a job? Well, until you get one - you can help a poor child with her homework. That can change her life. You have the potential to change someone’s life!!! Right now. But no!!! Cos that does not fit within your definition of ‘full life’ Tragedy #2: Have a job but not paying enough? Not getting the house you wanted? The vacation you wanted? Your friends’ FB status updates making you feel like a loser? You can pay the fees for a poor child’s year’s education. It might change his life!You can call up that lonely old relative. Spend 10 minutes talking. It could leave them with memories of a life time!You can simply cuddle with your spouse or take a 30 minute walk down the street without going to the mall and worrying about all the things you cannot buy! It can add to your life’s memories.Tragedy #3: Got only 6 months to live?Come on! Nothing can be worse than this, right? But exactly! Nothing can be worse anyway! What the hell will you do with all those savings? How does it matter who complains what you left for them or didn’t. Take a world trip, take a country trip, take a state trip. Do stuff that does not harm anybody but you thought were ‘morally not OK’. People might still write articles about how you ‘Made the best out of life’. They can DO it too. Right now. But they don’t do it. Instead, they choose to think about it.  You have the power to change lives, others’ and your own - right now. You have the power to be deeply happy - right now. You have ways to make the best out of life - right now. But those ways do not fit into your ideas of a full life. You are busy looking for something harder, bigger and longer. Which is ‘out there’ Refusing to consider it might be simpler, smaller and faster. And ‘right here’ A full life is not something you achieve at the end of a hollow, painful journey. A full life is simply a series of moments lived to the fullest.

Life becomes more deeply rewarding and fulfilling as we transform, through experience, our mere knowledge of ourselves and the world into wisdom. This inherently requires time and thus wisdom is generally acquired later in life. This is not immediately obvious to younger people because this world seems to belong to the young. The world cherishes and admires youth and youthful beauty so much that we quickly and mindlessly dismiss the unique and profound gifts of age which hold the keys to wisdom and meaning. When we are young our inexperience leads us to believe we are living life in its entirety. What we see, understand, and know seems not only to be where it's all at, constituting the only things of value, but that if we are not in the center of it all, if we are not young, cutting edge and sexy, we are unimportant, redundant, and seen as having no useful contribution. It takes time and experience to understand that we all start out with only one lens through which we view ourselves and the world. Our socialization, education and acculturation lead only to the world view that fits the current paradigm in which we exist. Only experience enables the paradigm shifts to occur that are necessary for us to see the world from more than one angle and through more than one lens. Probably the most important factor in achieving a fulfilling life is knowing who we truly are, knowing our own truth and desire. Our truth is the essence of who we are, what we want to do and be in life, regardless of what we have been raised to believe about ourselves, and despite what others (especially those we give our power to, those we admire and look to as role models) are saying and doing around us.  The only way we can learn who we truly are is through deep and varied life experiences. Just as when we choose a particular color of paint for our walls we need to see it in all different times of day and in various intensities of light, because it is astonishing how different one shade can be in different conditions.  When I was younger I always assumed that if I ever witnessed an accident or trauma I would always avail myself to help anyone in need. Then in my late 20s I was living in London and, walking one morning down Fleet Street to work, I caught sight of something above me. I looked up to see a body falling from several floors above. Acting on pure instinct alone, I turned away because, somewhere deep inside of me, I knew I could not witness the landing of the body on the pavement. I turned around and I never looked back. I did not stay to help. I did not hesitate in my desire and intention to escape. To this day I have no idea why I reacted this way, but this experience showed me how I actually do behave in such circumstances and it is now part of my self knowledge.  Some of our most instructive experiences occur in the times when we think no one is watching us, when we face temptation, when we have the opportunity for revenge, when we realize we have power over someone, or when we feel we don't have what we need and we feel very much like we may not survive. We have to go through many, many versions of these experiences till we get to the point where we choose thoughts, words and actions that conform to the version of ourselves that we aspire to be. Every experience has something new to show us about ourselves, who we are in every degree of light and shade, even those that seem repetitive and identical to previous experiences. This is because depth and intensity often require repetition. So when we feel we are drifting through life, that nothing we do is of any real value, it can be useful to remember that we are in the process of creating the ultimate work of art: our true selves. Then there are the traumatically disrupting experiences, that almost all of us have to endure at some point, where we experience deep loss (of a loved one, a job, a marriage, health or money) that shows us that so much of what we always believed to be true is, in fact, not. It is crucial to understand that our ability to find peace, love, happiness, and success - all the aspects of what we usually consider to be a "fulfilling" life - is directly related to our ability to accept the vast array of life's vicissitudes, no matter how disturbing or distressing they may be, because these loss experiences become the new and improved lens which ultimately provides sharper and more accurate views of life and love that eventually lead to meaning and wisdom. In addition to learning who we are, we must also learn what is our true desire. This is not as easy as it might seem. What we want to be and do has to be unpacked from all the social conditioning, beliefs and pressures that formed the first few versions of ourselves. This is usually a gradual process, a series of experiments where we test all the possible options until we have enough knowledge and experience to know what makes our heart and soul sing. ( I can safely say that for me, that does not include listening to hard rock, eating mass produced meat, or feeling obliged to read, and admire, the literary canon). And it is for this reason that whilst most over 50 would love to inhabit their 25 year old body again (most likely seeing that body with far greater love and acceptance than we did the first time round) almost none would want the young and inexperienced, often confused and insecure, 25 year old mind that goes with it.  When we have sufficient experience to accumulate great knowledge about ourselves, other people and the world, we are ready to develop a new set of skills: the subtle art of alchemy and transmutation. Knowledge is transformed into wisdom, and wisdom gives us the tools to embed our lives in love and truth. Life and experience teach us that love and truth, and the enlightenment and meaning they lead to, are the only things of any true and lasting value.

Work on your mental health. Your mind is as important as the rest of your body, and it's important that you practice good mental health. This includes meeting your emotional needs. Feeling emotionally well can help you see positive changes in the rest of your life. You can improve your mental health by surrounding yourself with people that you trust and making sure that you are comfortable in your surroundings. If you are experiencing unpleasant emotions, such as sadness or loneliness, it is possible that seeing a mental health professional would be useful. Find a reputable counselor in your area.Try planning something fun to do at least once a week. This could be as simple as arranging a standing coffee date with a good friend. Having something to look forward to can really help you feel more mentally balanced.Learn to handle stress. Stress is one of the biggest problems people face when trying to improve their mental health. Try finding coping mechanisms to use when you are in a difficult situation, such as taking deep breaths or counting to ten. Get organized. Keeping a to-do list or calendar can be a great way to manage your hectic life. Try this method to ease the stress of your busy life.Get physically fit. Taking care of your body is crucial for overall health. People who are more physically fit are generally happier and have lower rates of stress. Take good care of yourself by eating a heathy diet and getting regular exercise. Get moving. Joining a gym is a great way to get healthy and interact with other people. Look for one in your neighborhood. Walking is also a great way to get some physical activity each day. Physical exercise can also provide you with a much needed break from work.Eat lots of fruits and veggies. People who eat a balanced diet are less likely to suffer from health problems, such as high cholesterol or diabetes.Be spiritually healthy. Spiritual wellness means being in tune with your beliefs and values. In order to get in touch with your spiritual side, try to think about what is most important to you, and focus on those things. You can also consider what you believe is your purpose in life. Being spiritual means being mindful. Try using methods such as mediation or yoga to increase your spiritual well being.Enhance your interpersonal relationships. Your interactions with other people can have a big impact on your well being. Involving yourself in positive relationships can make you feel happier and less stressed. If you have negative people in your life, it can cause you to feel unhappy and unhealthy. If you are in a romantic relationship, make it a priority to improve it. Try spending more quality time with your partner and being more physically affectionate.Improve other relationships. Your relationships at work are also important to your well being. Try to find common interests with your coworkers to enhance your bond. You can also try volunteering to help them if you notice they are swamped. Focus on your friends and family. Your closest relationships are often with your pals and your relatives. Make sure to schedule time to spend with them.Increase your intellectual health. You need to strengthen your mind the same way you strengthen your other muscles. Being intellectually healthy means that you challenge and engage your brain. You are curious and like to explore new places and things.  Travel to new places. This is one of the best ways to learn new things and stimulate your mind.Do puzzles. There are many things you can do at home to stretch your brain. Try crossword puzzles, Sudoku, or challenging board games. Start fresh each day. If things aren't going your way, try to take some of the pressure off of yourself. Look at each day as a new beginning. This mindset will help you be able to see the positives in life. Try journaling before bed each night. Writing down your thoughts can help you sleep better and start each day with a clear mind.Be proactive. In order for your life to change, you need to be the force that drives changes. Being proactive means that you are in charge of your own destiny. You respond to your own choices, not choices made by other people. When you feel in charge of your own life, you will start to feel more comfortable and confident. To be proactive, think about specific actions that you can take to improve your life, and then take them. For example, if you are unhappy with your job, a proactive step to change that would be to update your resume and start applying for new jobs.Form new habits. If there are parts of your life that you feel are not the best they could be, try to make changes. Maybe you want to improve your physical fitness or maybe you want to save more money. Whatever it is, try making changes in your daily life in order to see big changes. For example, try setting aside $2 a day as a way to start saving more money. A habit typically takes two months to really become part of your routine, so be patient with yourself.Set Goals. Goals are a reflection of your priorities and are concrete ways that you can improve your life. Goal setting can be useful in every area of your life. Having realistic goals can help you visualize the changes you want to see happen. Set both long-term and short-term goals. When you see results from the short-term goals, that will give you the encouragement you need to persevere and make long term changes.Find your Passions. Having a purpose in your life can help you to live the best life possible. Try asking yourself what you would do if you no longer had to worry about money. When you find the answer, you're on your way to find your passion. Follow your curiosity. Your passion is unique to you, but it will definitely be something your find both interesting and challenging. For example, if you love animals, find a way to work with them. You could begin by volunteering at your local shelter. Appreciate something each day. Try to put some effort into truly taking pleasure out of your life. One simple way to do this is to choose something to take pleasure in every day. This can be as simple as taking a moment to taste and savor your morning coffee. Or you could make it a habit to spend thirty minutes each day doing something that you truly enjoy. Avoid Comaparations. Try not to measure your life against someone else's. For example, if you are concerned about your finances, try to think of ways to increase your income. This is an action you can take to improve your situation as opposed to thinking about your friend who has a higher paying job and wondering why you can't make that kind of money. When you compare yourself to someone else, you often end up judging yourself unfavorably. Most people compare themselves with those we perceive as having more or being "better." They also tend to compare themselves to an idealized version of that person, ignoring the fact that the other person is human, with flaws and challenges like everyone else. Instead of measuring yourself against others, compare your past and present selves. How have you grown in the last year? What can you do today that you couldn't do before?Comparing yourself to another person is like comparing apples to oranges. It is an inaccurate and irrelevant measurement, since everyone is unique. It's as illogical as comparing your swimming ability to a dolphin's.Go outside. Research tells us that fresh air can have a positive impact on your health, both mental and physical. Try to take some time each day (or week) to spend some time outdoors. You can visit your neighborhood park, or go on a weekend adventure to a nearby state park. Practice self-acceptance. Focus on your positive traits. If you are overly critical of yourself, it can be hard to find pleasure in your life. Instead, take some time each day to focus on your strengths. Make it a habit to compliment yourself. Try taping a sticky note to your bathroom mirror that reminds you that you are a great person.Be playful. Embracing your inner child can help you feel like you are living life to the fullest. Try doing something silly, like skipping or turning a cartwheel. Don't be afraid to laugh. You can also make it a habit to joke around with your your friends and family. Your playfulness will likely rub of on them. source: How to Live the Best Life You Can
